contentrichtext.text: {{Other people|John Horsley}} '''John Horsley''' (c. 1685–12 January 1732) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[antiquarian]], known primarily for his book ''[[Britannia Romana]]'' or ''The Roman Antiquities of Britain'' which was published in 1732. ==Early life== [[John Hodgson (antiquary)|John Hodgson]], in a memoir published in 1831, held that Horsley was born in 1685, at [[Pinkie House]], in the parish of [[Inveresk]], [[Midlothian]], and that his father was a Northumberland [[nonconformist]], who had migrated to [[Scotland]], but returned to England soon after the [[Glorious Revolution]] of 1688. John Hodgson Hinde, in the ''[[Archaeologia Aeliana]]'' of February 1865, held that he was a native of [[Newcastle-on-Tyne]], the son of Charles Horsley, a member of the Tailors' Company of the town. David Boyd Haycock writing in the ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'' comments that none of the suggestions made for Horsley's background is verifiable.<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=13819|title=Horsley, John|first=David Boyd|last=Haycock}}</ref> He was educated at the [[Royal Grammar School, Newcastle]]<ref>http://www.seaham.i12.com/myers/m-horsley.html</ref><ref>http://links.jstor.org/sici?sici=0075-4358(1932)22%3C161%3AJH%3E2.0.CO%3B2-G</ref> and at [[Edinburgh University]], where he graduated [[Master's degree|MA]] on 29 April 1701. There is evidence that he "was settled in [[Morpeth, Northumberland|Morpeth]] as a [[Presbyterian]] minister as early as 1709." Hodgson, however, thought that up to 1721, at which time he was residing at [[Widdrington Station and Stobswood|Widdrington]], "he had not received ordination, but preached as a licentiate." ==Educator== Horsley communicated to the ''[[Philosophical Transactions]]'' notes on the rainfall at Widdrington in the years 1722 and 1723. At Morpeth Horsley opened a private school, attracting pupils irrespective of religious connection, among them [[Newton Ogle]], later dean of Westminster. He gave lectures on [[mechanics]] and [[hydrostatics]] in Morpeth, [[Alnwick]] and Newcastle, and was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] on 23 April 1730, or in May, 1729.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www2.royalsociety.org/DServe/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqCmd=Show.tcl&dsqDb=Persons&dsqPos=0&dsqSearch=%28Surname%3D%27horsley%27%29 |title = Library and Archive Catalogue| publisher= Royal Society|accessdate= 21 November 2010}}</ref> ==Death== Horsley died of [[apoplexy]] on 12 January 1732, on the eve of the publication of the ''Britannia Romana''. ==Works== It is as an archaeologist and antiquarian that Horsley is now known. His major work, ''[[Britannia Romana]]'', or ''The Roman Antiquities of Britain'' was published in 1732. One of Horsley's achievements in this book was to identify for the first time which [[Roman legion|legion]]s of the [[Roman army]] were stationed in Britain.<ref>[http://www.ancient-warfare.com/pdf/web/AWIV-5/fateoftheninth.pdf Cf. Duncan Campbell's article, p. 49 ]</ref> There was in the [[British Museum]] a copy of with notes by [[John Ward (academic)|John Ward]]. He also published two sermons and a handbook to his lectures on mechanics, etc., and projected a history of Northumberland and [[Durham]], collections for which were found among his papers. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{1911|article=John Horsley|url=http://www.1911encyclopedia.org/John_Horsley}} {{Authority control|VIAF=42187630}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Horsley, John | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1685 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1732 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Horsley, John}} [[Category:1685 births]] [[Category:1732 deaths]] [[Category:People from Morpeth, Northumberland]] [[Category:People educated at the Royal Grammar School, Newcastle]] [[Category:British antiquarians]] [[Category:British historians]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]]
